Canterburys garden, " the poor come 
                
                  kkocking
                  knocking
                 at the gate
and my man says "Sir, there is some one at the gate would

speak with 
                
                  oyu
                  you
                ." So he laid aside his book and went
out anong the poor. He visited them in their hovels. He
noted their poverty. Re saw the poor man unable now
to buy a goose, for the great lords were enclosing the
fields. He went to the great man and found him still in

bed, after his hunting 
                
                  anf hid
                  and his
                 hawking. He saw the poor 
                
                  sutis
                  suitors

waiting 
                
                  ho
                  hour
                 in the hall to get their suit 
                
                  herad
                  heard
                .
These were the casees that he brought before King Edward

In a voice that 
                
                  sumbles
                  stumbles
                 and uses the old language of
his fathers house, ))" they say in my country to the hogs
mingle mangle, cum pur, cum pur" --- he brought into the
light of day the hidden [illeg.] and suffering
present moment the harlot going to execution at Newgate

and saying as she went "that 
                
                   f
                  if
                 good fellows had kept
touch with her, she had not bin at this time in that case."

He saw the curates   in their 
                
                  velevet
                  velvet
                 shoes and slippers
meet to dance the morris dance. And the fine ladies

dressed in 
                
                  vardinaglls
                  vardingalls
                 with their hair puffed out in tussocks

He saw the 
                
                  yo ng
                  young
                 men given over in the s t to gulling 
                
                  drinm ig
                  drinking
and whoring. The young men dice away their thrift; Instead of

shooting with the long

                  bow
                 they their sports are lost

turned into bowling 
                
                  drinming
                  drinking
                 and whoring. He And the poor
are still going on pilgrimages, setting up candles and
[illeg.]

wirshipping
                  worshipping
                 pigs bones. [illeg.] He casts the light of the new
learning upon the the old superstitions. He too, until he

thirty "had walked in the shadow of 
                
                  d ath
                  death
                ." It was Master

Boilney
                  Bilney
                 at 
                
                  Ca, fiege
                  Cambridge
                 who 
                
                  ppened
                  opened
                 his eyes; Master Bilney

who went about among the poor and the 
                
                  sivk
                  sick
                ,

Master Bilney heard him preach 
                
                  agianst
                  against
                 
                  
                    Melnchton
                    Melancthon
                   and his

opinons. and desired me for Gods sake to hear his 
                
                  confessio
                  confession
"did so; and to say the very truth, by his confession

I learnt ed more than for many 
                
                  yeares
                  yeares
                . With Bilney he 
                
                  vi ted
                  visited

the 
                
                  prisones
                  prisoners
                 in the Tower at Cambridge, for he was ever 
                
                  visig
                  visiting

pirsoners
                  prisoners
                 
                
                  andsick
                  and sick
                 folk. There was a woman who had killed
her child. And Latimer brought her story before King

Hnery
                  Henry
                 the eighth as he talked with him after the sermon in

the gallery. and he got her 
                
                  padrdon
                  pardon
                . Master Bilney was burnt;

so it may wi be, he will be burnt. 
                
                  eanehile
                  Meanwhile
                 he will speak

the truth so that the 
                
                  simp le
                  simple
                 can understand. In their own

tongue. Standing on the verge of the 
                
                  Elizabetha
                  Elizabethan
                 age,
he saw, as Harrison saw, the great buildings rise on the

foundations of the old. "There 
                
                  ws
                  was
                 never such buildings then

as 
                
                  if
                  is
                 now, planting, nor marrying." And yet the 
                
                  Englis
                  English
                 are

still sunk in 
                
                  supe stition
                  superstition
                . Give 
                
                  thmoey
                  the money
                 he implores that

was wont to bestow on 
                
                  pilgrimagesmatters
                  pilgrimages matters
                , in trentalls
in masses, in purgatory matters" to poor men sons so that

they may become 
                
                  schlars
                  scholars
                . "There be now none but greate mens
sons in colleges." It will come to pass that

we 
                    
                      shallhave
                      shall have
                     nothing but a little 
                    
                      Ebglish
                      English
                     divinity, that will
bring the realm into a very barbarousness, and utter
decay of learning."

This was the voice of the new 
                
                  lraning
                  learning
                , the 
                
                  vo ce
                  voice

that ousted 
                
                  superstiti,n
                  superstition
                , the voice of reason, charity, common

sense. But it was by an 
                
                  irnoy
                  irony
                 ironically enough, the
the preacher who was for banishing Robin Hoodand such

supersitions
                  superstitions
                 was forging the very weapon 
                
                  theat
                  that
                 give the old

mibstrels
                  minstrels
                 a new lease of life. His English. When he
said the Lords prayer at the beginning and at

the end of his 
                
                  ermon
                  sermon
                 he was putting English into high places.
He was rescuing it from the back door. He was teaching

Spenser and 
                
                  Shakespere
                  Shakespeare
                 how to write.
[The house was being?]
Both Harrison and Latimer see the very same house

the 
                
                  hose
                  house
                 that was being built on the foundations of the
old house. We can still see the great Elizabethan house
whose building vas to both preacher and antiquary a
sign of the decay of luxury. in all its glory.

There it is, standing in its green island of Park 
                
                  seapareted
                  separated

often from the high road by only a 
                
                  d p
                  dip
                 in the ground and a

low red wall. With its 
                
                  congloeration
                  conglomeration
                 of roofs and chapels

and 
                
                  chimeys
                  chimneys
                 
                
                  i
                  it
                 dwarfs its 
                
                  neighboyrs
                  neighbours
                . Inside all is kept as

if the Queen Elizabeth were expected. The upright 
                
                  Elizabetahn
                  Elizabethan

chairs stand round the walls. Their 
                
                  ftinges
                  fittings
                 and tapestry
are not much faded. The great oak tables are heavy

and polished. The 
                
                  carbed
                  carved
                 chairs and cupboards look 
                
                  barnd
                  brand
new. The floor is strewn with carpets; cut glass chandeliers

hang down from the decorated 
                
                  pl ter
                  plaster
                 work on the 
                
                  celing
                  ceiling
                .

Even knick knacks 
                
                  ha v
                  have
                 survived; the inlaid work box,

the and the pear shaped 
                
                  l te
                  lute
                 on which the Queen once
played.
But the Elizabethans themselves are silent. Only
the furniture remains,, stiff and ornate, fantastic and

uncushioned
                  uncushioned
                .

Latimer had read the 
                
                  Lord
                  Lord's
                 Prayer in English. The Bible
was printed in English. And, using the prose of the bible

when they write prose, the 
                
                  Elixabethans
                  Elizabethans
                 are 
                
                  unknwon
                  unknown
                 to us.
When in some extremity of anguish or fear they take up the

pen they use the 
                
                  rhyms
                  rhythms
                 of the Bible. 
                
                  Itis
                  It is
                 a garment only

to be worn when the mind is in the right 
                
                  attidtue
                  attitude
                . They can

say nothing simple, subtle, or 
                
                  breif
                  brief
                . At 
                  
                    Gorham nury
                    Gorhambury
                   Lady
Ann Bacon sat writing to her son. But her letters are like

seroms
                  sermons
                , or 
                
                  satte doucments
                  state documents
                , intricate, involved,

She 
                
                  e hosrts
                  exhorts
                 God keep us sound in the faith
and send us health and a care to please God before all."
She admonishes Be not speedy of speech, nor talk

suuddenly
                  suddenly
                , 
                
                    discrteion
                    discretion
                
                
                  requieth
                  requireth
                 and that
soberly then..." If she has to descend to an actual object

a basket of 
                
                  starwberries
                  strawberries
                 it is with c dark 
                
                  insintuat ons
                  insinuations
                .

Greek and 
                
                  atin
                  Latin
                 come as easily to her pen as

English. There is no 
                
                  gaity
                  gaiety
                , no freedom no 
                
                  familairty
                  familiarity

in this world. Fear of God, 
                
                  suspciion
                  suspicion
                 of man surround

the writer as with the 
                
                  wlls
                  walls
                 of a dungeon. The wall may

conceal a Lady Ann 
                
                  whois
                  who is
                merry and gay; it may conceal

must 
                
                  cobneceal
                  conceal
                 passion, laughter and sorrow;
but no one can tell who it is that lives on the other side

of the wall of formal 
                  langauge
                  language
                .
